doc.field: The collection consists of a document recording the naturalization in the County Court of Kings County, New York on October 13, 1857 of John Comyns, a teenaged Irish immigrant living in Brooklyn, New York. Included are two sworn oaths and a certification by a county clerk in 1894 of the authenticity of the copy of the record.

The collection consists of a document recording the naturalization in the County Court of Kings County, New York on October 13, 1857 of John Comyns, a teenaged Irish immigrant living in Brooklyn, New York. Included are two sworn oaths and a certification by a county clerk in 1894 of the authenticity of the copy of the record.

This collection consists of a document certified on December 5, 1894 by a clerk of the County Court of Kings County, New York as being a true transcript of the original record contained in his office. The document contains two oaths sworn in open court on October 13, 1857, one by Patrick Comyns regarding John Comyns' residency and character in the United States and one by John Comyns renouncing his allegiance to other states, particularly to the Queen of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, as well as an order of the court admitting John Comyns as a citizen of the United States.
John Comyns immigrated to the United States prior to the age of 18. He became a naturalized citizen of the United States in 1857.
John Comyns immigrated to the United States prior to the age of 18. He became a naturalized citizen of the United States in 1857 by order of a Kings County, New York court.
